item.title: vanderveer's disappointment tempered by selection to hall
item.description: tara vanderveer could not lead stanford to a national title, but she will be inducted into the naismith hall of fame this year.

item.title: wisconsin governor releases bond restructuring bill
item.description: wisconsin governor scott walker released on wednesday bond restructuring and other plans to close a current year budget gap that were cut from a controversial law to curb the powers of public sector unions.

item.title: diet high in fish linked to stronger bones
item.description: older adults who eat greater amounts of fish end up preserving their bone density better than people who don't eat as much fish, a new study finds.

item.title: observatory: silk production takes a walk on the wild side
item.description: using an acidic solution to remove the mineral layer that coats wild silkworms' cocoons may make them easier to work with, oxford researchers say.

item.title: powerful brazil chief of staff resigns after scandal
item.description: the most powerful pro-business voice in brazil's government resigned on tuesday following a scandal over his sudden enrichment, prompting worries on wall street that his departure could herald a leftward drift in economic policy.

item.title: alcatel ceo looks to future growth
item.description: chief executive ben verwaayen is preparing the next stage of telecom equipment maker alcatel-lucent's development armed with a refreshed product portfolio and a slimmer cost structure.

item.title: news analysis: president underscores similarities with brazilians, but ignores one
item.description: in a visit to one of the most racially diverse countries in the americas, president obama once again seemed to sidestep mentioning his own racial background.

item.description: aguilera, green, levine and shelton agree: the new nbc reality show is about building contestants up, not tearing them down.

item.title: stosur untroubled on low-key sunday start
item.description: gusty winds and half-empty stands gave no sense of the usual parisian glamour as last year's french open runner-up samantha stosur began with an easy win on sunday and lleyton hewitt pulled out injured.

item.title: bore-hole cameras find void near trapped idaho miner
item.description: search teams snaking a tiny camera through newly drilled bore holes have found a void in the rubble of a cave-in that trapped an idaho silver miner, the first sign in five days that he might have survived.

item.description: median ceo pay jumped 27 darsad in 2010, a analysis of data from governancemetrics international found.

item.title: your money: consider the worst case with zipcar
item.description: zipcar caps the liability insurance coverage it provides for members at $300,000 per incident, which could leave drivers involved in an accident exposed to an expensive lawsuit.

item.description: amid battles on health care, the federal budget and the deficit, another fight is brewing on capitol hill this week -- over light bulbs.

item.title: sharapova makes a return to the semifinals

item.title: teams that score first in playoff games are tough to beat

item.title: obama urges companies to hire, studies housing moves

item.title: boston scientific ceo to step down in december

item.title: american airlines flight diverted to vegas over smoke
item.description: an american airlines flight bound for san francisco with 166 people on board made an emergency landing in las vegas on friday after the crew smelled smoke in the cockpit, a federal aviation spokesman said.

item.title: nigerian vote aborted after ballot paper chaos

item.title: observers praise haiti vote, urge transparent count
item.description: u-prince - the international community gave its blessing on monday to haiti's presidential run-off and urged haitians to calmly wait for the first results due next week to ensure a credible, transparent outcome.

item.description: royal dutch shell posted stronger than expected first-quarter profit thanks to higher oil prices and wider margins in its refining business, boosting hopes for a more generous dividend policy.

item.title: a year on, mystery shrouds thailand's deadly unrest
item.description: a 30-meter (98-ft) corrugated iron wall masks the remnants of a mysterious arson attack a year ago on southeast asia's second-biggest shopping mall, a reminder of thailand's struggle to tame a crisis many fear could turn violent again during elections.

item.title: fed's lacker says must let ailing big firms fail
item.description: large financial firms should be allowed to fail or they will continue to take excess risks that lead to crises, richmond federal reserve president jeffrey lacker said on thursday.

item.description: they say there's a gadget for just about everything. that now includes boots which detect radiation and a kangaroo tail for weary humans.

item.title: south dakota eases state uranium mining rules
item.description: the governor of south dakota on tuesday signed into law a bill to ease oversight of a proposed uranium mine near a popular tourist destination despite protests from environmental groups.

item.description: tampa bay lightning assistant coach wayne fleming is recovering from an operation to remove a brain tumor.

item.title: tyler hamilton gives '04 gold to usada after doping admission
item.description: tyler hamilton has given his 2004 cycling gold medal to the united states anti-doping agency.

item.title: can tiger win the masters? absolutely, he says
item.description: tiger woods put himself into 'masters mode' sunday, ending weeks of introspective analysis to state confidently and simply that he can win the u.s. masters for a fifth time next month.

item.title: japan crisis spurs survival planning by u.s. mormons
item.description: while the nuclear crisis in japan unfolds a continent away, mormon-dominated communities in the western united states say the disaster overseas is bringing close to home a lesson about preparing for the worst.

item.title: as china ages, birthrate policy may prove difficult to reverse
item.description: as china's population grows older, the government may relax the one-child policy that has lowered the country's birthrate, but that may not greatly change what is now established practice.
